paper_metadata.title: Impacts of a Government-Implemented Cash Plus Program on Violence Among Tanzanian Adolescents

program_information.program_name: Tanzania Social Action Fund (TASAF) Cash Plus Program
program_information.target_population: Adolescents aged 14-19 years in households receiving government cash transfer

component_a_cash_support.cash_evidence_citation: During round 3 fieldwork, households experienced a delay in PSSN payments for the first time

component_b_assets.assets_evidence_citation: the productive grant was disbursed shortly before round 3

study_characteristics.outcomes_evidence_citation: We estimated intent-to-treat impacts on violence experiences, violence perpetration, and pathways of impact. | There were no intervention impacts on emotional violence, physical violence, or help seeking. Examining pathways, we found positive impacts on self-esteem and participation in livestock tending and, among female participants, a positive impact on sexual debut delays and a negative effect on school attendance.
study_characteristics.design_evidence_citation: We used data from a cluster randomized controlled trial (n 5 130 communities)

evidence_citations.program_name_citation: We used data from a longitudinal cluster randomized controlled trial (n 5 130 communities), which was implemented by United Nations Children's Fund (UNI-CEF) Office of Research-Innocenti, University at Buffalo, and EDI Global, in collaboration with Tanzania Social Action Fund (TASAF)
evidence_citations.country_citation: conducted in the Mbeya and Iringa regions of Tanzania
evidence_citations.target_population_citation: The panel sample comprised 904 adolescents aged 14 to 19 years living in households receiving a government cash transfer
